review.title: An HMM Based Named Entity Recognition System for Indian Languages: The JU System at ICON 2013
review.abstract: This paper reports about our work in the ICON 2013 NLP TOOLS CONTEST on Named Entity Recognition. We submitted runs for Bengali, English, Hindi, Marathi, Punjabi, Tamil and Telugu. A statistical HMM (Hidden Markov Models) based model has been used to implement our system. The system has been trained and tested on the NLP TOOLS CONTEST: ICON 2013 datasets. Our system obtains F-measures of 0.8599, 0.7704, 0.7520, 0.4289, 0.5455, 0.4466, and 0.4003 for Bengali, English, Hindi, Marathi, Punjabi, Tamil and Telugu respectively.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Named entity recognition involves the localization and classification of the names in the text. The goal of the designated entity recognition is the identification and classification of each word / term in a document into some predefined categories such as person name, location name, organization name, other NLP applications (date, time, percentage and monetary expressions etc.) and "none-of-the-above." NER is an important task with applications in information extraction, questionnaire, machine translation, summary and other NLP applications. This paper presents an HMM (Hidden Markov Model) based on NER system for Indian languages developed for the ICON 2013 NLP tool competition, the goal of which is to perform NE recognition in a variety of ways: artifact, entry, facilities, location, locomotive, materials, organization, person, plants, number, distance, money, quantity, date, period, and yearly contest.

sections.heading: 2 Training Data
sections.text: The system converts the data of the SSF format into the IOB format prior to the training, and the data converted to the IOB format is used for the training. IOB format uses a B-XXX tag that specifies the first word of a unit of type XXX and I-XXX that is used for the following words of a unit. The tag "O" indicates that the word is outside of a NE (i.e. not part of a designated unit). An additional tag EXXX (which is not part of the IOB format) is added to the tag set to represent the last word of a unit of type XXX.At the time of system development, we observed that the data (training, development and testing) provided by the organizers of the ICON 2013 NLP tool competition contain several error types, such as ambiguous POS tags (XC:?, QO:? etc.), errors in the NE tagging. sections.heading: 4 Evaluation and Results
sections.text: After obtaining the NE-marked output in IOB format from the HMM model, we found that the marked output contains some occurrences of a sequence of I-XXXs where the left boundary of each such sequence is a transition from tag "O" to I-XXXs (according to the IOB format, the left boundary of a named unit is a transition from any day to B-XXX). We also observed that the word sequence associated with this type of tag sequence is not really a named entity. If we consider this an error of the model, we replace such a sequence of I-XXXs in the output with a sequence of "o." After performing this post-processing on the output of the HMM model, the final output file is produced. Our developed NERS system was evaluated with traditional precision, recall, and F-measure.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper describes a designated entity recognition system for Indian languages, namely Bengali, English, Hindi, Marathi, Punjabi, Tamil and Telugu. The designated entity recognition system was developed on the basis of the Visual Basic platform, so that a suitable user interface can be designed for beginners. The system was designed so that only changing the training corpus in a file can make the system portable to a new Indian language.
